(CBS) QUOTE OF THE DAY
“To be great is to be misunderstood.” - Ralph Waldo Emerson 
      

TODAY’S TRIVIA California's Frank Epperson invented the 
      Popsicle in 1905 when he was 11-years-old. 

TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWS Here's an early look 
      at what we are working on for tonight's broadcast of the CBS EVENING NEWS 
      from Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric... Hi everyone, 
      Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is in Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, 
      today at an international conference on Iraq. There’s been one significant 
      development already – debt relief for that war-torn country. But the even 
      bigger news might be the rare contact today between U.S. officials and 
      those from Syria. Sheila MacVicar is there and will have more. 
      Our national security correspondent David Martin will 
      report on the diplomatic talks going on in Sharm el Sheik. And 
      Elizabeth Palmer will report from the Tehran stock exchange, where 
      investors are hoping the meeting will open the way to greener financial 
      pastures. Eighteen months before the 2008 election, ten Republican 
      presidential contenders will take the stage at the Ronald Reagan 
      presidential library outside of Los Angeles for their first debate. 
      Sandra Hughes is there. And Secret Service protection is 
      being given to one of the Democratic presidential candidates: Barack 
      Obama. It is the earliest in any presidential campaign that protection has 
      been authorized for a candidate. Due to what Menu Foods is calling 
      possible cross-contamination, the pet food maker expanded its recall 
      today. This news comes as a study shows it might not be the melamine in 
      food itself that is harmful, but the combination of certain chemicals. 
      Nancy Cordes will have this and more. Thousands of people 
      jammed Capitol Square in Richmond, Virginia, today hoping to get a glimpse 
      of Queen Elizabeth. She and her husband, Prince Philip, began their 
      six-day stay in the United States today – their first in 16 years. Mark 
      Phillips will report. Do you have a favorite to win the Run 
      for the Roses? Sharyn Alfonsi will give you a peek at some of the 
      horses running in this Saturday’s Kentucky Derby. You’ll also meet a young 
      woman who paid $9,000 for a horse that will be pitted in that race against 
      million-dollar thoroughbreds. And today we lost a pioneer, 
      astronaut Wally Schirra. I’ll tell you about his amazing life. 
      Thanks, Katie For more on two of the stories 
      noted above, please click on the following links: Rice 
      Talks Iraq With Top Syrian Official Click Here Space Pioneer Wally 
      Schirra Dies At 84 Click Here Here's a look at one 
      of the stories we are working on for Friday's broadcast of the CBS Evening 
      News A cherished legacy is reclaimed ... through an entire COUNTY'S 
      collective memory, some SWEAT, and REAL divinity. A very special candy 
      store on this week's Assignment America...That story and much more Friday night on the CBS Evening News.

      evening@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON DAVID LETTERMAN Join Dave tonight on 
      The Late Show with actress Marcia Cross 
      AND impressionist Joe Piscopo… Plus, musical guest Tori Amos! 

FRIDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOW Harry Smith, 
      Hannah Storm, Julie Chen and Russ Mitchell anchor 
      THE EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave 
      Price will bring us the weather from aboard Freedom of the Seas at 
      Cape Liberty Cruise Port in Bayonne, NJ. Along with the top 
      news of the day, we will also have the following stories:
CSI BEHIND THE SCENES: Centuries ago... did humans mate 
      with reptilian creatures from another planet? That is a central question 
      in Thursday night's episode of CSI. But there was another question 
      we wanted an answer to. How did they transform one of the show's stars... 
      into a lizard? Our own Julie Chen visited the set to find out. 
      Friday morning, we’ll see what she discovered when she went behind the 
      scenes of the hit show. TOBEY MAGUIRE: Well the wait is 
      finally over, as the highly anticipated Spiderman 3 hits theaters 
      Friday. The first two Spiderman films each set opening weekend box 
      office records, and the latest film doesn't look to disappoint. Once 
      again, Tobey Maguire suits up as your friendly neighborhood Spiderman, who 
      this time must fight three villains, including his best friend Harry. And 
      Maguire is riding high: father to five-month-old Ruby, he is basking in 
      the glow of new fatherhood. How has it changed this down-to-earth actor, a 
      self-professed homebody? We’ll find out when we speak to Tobey Friday 
      morning. VEGETABLE HARVEST: PATRICIA WELLS: Bestselling 
      author and culinary teacher Patricia Wells is an American, but is 
      considered one of the foremost experts when it comes to French cuisine. 
      Friday morning, she will join us with recipes from her latest cookbook, 
      Vegetable Harvest. SURVIVOR CASTOFF: Stranded in 
      Fiji, the competition heats up for the remaining survivors battling it out 
      for the million-dollar prize. The Immunity idol becomes a hot topic when 
      Yau-Man is blackmailed into revealing his position by Mookie and Alex. How 
      will that impact what is left of the Four Horsemen? And who will be voted 
      off the island? On Friday morning, we'll have a recap of the new episode 
      and as always, talk to the next castoff about what really went wrong. 
      DECORATING WITH PATTERNS: Nothing livens up a room quite 
      like a bold pattern. If using a pattern in your home sounds risky, not so 
      says design expert Susanna Salk. With thoughtful mixing and matching 
      patterns are a great way to liven up any room in your home. From the 
      Pottery Barn flagship store in New York, Susanna will show us some easy 
      ways you can use pattern in your own decorating. If you would like 
      more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on 
      the following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com 
      

SATURDAY ON 48 HOURS 
      MYSTERY, 9PM/8C Here's an early preview of what you can 
      expect to see this Saturday on 48 HOURS MYSTERY, POWER, PASSION AND 
      POISON from Correspondent, Troy 
      Roberts: "Kathy Augustine was a rising star in Nevada state 
      politics. Smart, ambitious, tough and attractive she quickly ascended to 
      one of the highest offices in the state and many expected she'd eventually 
      end up working in national politics. But last year Kathy Augustine was 
      found unconscious in her bed and later died at the hospital. She was 
      fifty-years-old. At first it was assumed that Augustine died from a heart 
      attack. But her family and friends didn't believe it could be possible. 
      Augustine had her annual physical just a week before her death. She was 
      given a clean bill of health and there was no family history of heart 
      disease. It just didn't add up. Toxicology tests were ordered on 
      fluid samples taken from Augustine and the results shocked everyone. 
      Traces of the powerful paralytic drug Succinylcholine were found in her 
      system. The drug is normally given to patients to ease the insertion of a 
      breathing tube. It acts fast and nearly vanishes from the body within 
      minutes...making it extremely difficult to detect. Suspicions quickly fell 
      on Augustine's husband of three years, Chazz Higgs. The pair seemed an 
      unlikely couple. He was eight-years her junior. He was a bodybuilder who 
      had three failed marriages behind him. His relationship with Kathy was 
      troubled as well. In the months leading up to Augustine's death they had 
      discussed divorce. But there was more. Chaz Higgs was a critical care 
      nurse and he had access to Succincolyine. He knew how to adminster it and, 
      most importantly, he knew the drug could be potentially deadly. And then a 
      witness came forward with a damning claim about his allegedly role in the 
      crime. Chazz Higgs goes on trial for the murder of Kathy Augustine 
      next month. Higgs claims he is innocent. When we sat down for the 
      interview, that you'll see this weekend, he agreed to talk about the 
      charges against him...charges that could send him to prison for life, and 
      you'll hear his theories on who would want his wife dead...and why. I hope 
      you'll join us on Saturday night." Troy Roberts
(48 Hours Mystery airs Saturday at 10pmET/9CT)

SUNDAY ON 60 
      MINUTES, 7:00PM/6:00PM CT INSIDE THE ENEMY CAMP -- 
      Until Osama bin Laden declared all Americans and Jews fair targets for al 
      Qaeda terror, Nazir Abas trained Muslim militants in the jungles of South 
      East Asia. Now he provides valuable intelligence to authorities in the war 
      on terror. Bob Simon reports. LOU DOBBS -- Lesley 
      Stahl profiles the CNN anchor, whose stance against illegal 
      immigration has helped raise his ratings but also fueled criticism. 
      THRIFT SHOP MASTERPEICE? -- Teri Horton knew nothing about 
      art when she bought a big, drippy painting for five dollars years ago in a 
      thrift store. But now she says a fingerprint proves it is a $50 million 
      Jackson Pollock original. Anderson Cooper reports.
